coredata.dc:title: An infrared study of the oxidation of carbon monoxide over supported rhodium catalysts
coredata.dc:creator: Dai, C.H.
Worley, S.D.
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
The reaction of carbon monoxide and oxygen over supported rhodium films has been studied using infrared spectroscopy. The focus of the work was the reactivity of the various CO/Rh/X (X = Al2O3, SiO2, TiO2) surface states for supported catalysts having high and low Rh loading. Under the reaction conditions the “linear CO” species was the most stable toward oxidation, but this could have been a result of an oxidized Rh surface. A new CO/Rh surface species has been proposed which exhibits an infrared band at 2000 cm−1 for a 0.5% Rh/TiO2 film. This species is believed to be a bridged carbonyl between Rh1+ and the TiO2 support.

xocs:doc.xocs:rawtext: Volume 114, number 3 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 1 March 1985 AN INFRARED STUDY OF THE OXIDATION OF CARBON MONOXIDE OVER SUPPORTED RHODIUM CATALYSTS C.H. DAI and S.D. WORLEY Department of Chemistry, Auburn University, Auburn, AL 36849, USA Received 21 September 1984; in final form 4 December 1984 The reaction of carbon monoxide and oxygen over supported rhodium films has been studied using infrared spectroscopy. The focus of the work was the reactivity of the various CO/Rh/X (X = A1203, Si02, Ti02) surface states for supported catalysts having high and low Rh loading. Under the reaction conditions the "linear CO" species was the most stable toward oxidation, but this could have been a result of an oxidized Rh surface. A new CO/Rh surface species has been proposed which exhibits an infrared band at 2000 cm-1 for a 0.5% Rh/Ti02 film. This species is believed to be a bridged carbonyl between Rhl+and the TiOz support. 1. Introduction Although numerous studies of the catalytic hydrogenation of CO over supported Rh catalysts have been reported [1], the oxidation reaction for CO over these catalysts has received considerably less attention. It is well established that the oxidation of CO over Rh at moderate temperatures generally follows a Langmuir-Hinshelwood mechanism having negative order in carbon monoxide and positive order in oxygen with the reaction of CO(a) + O(a) being the rate-determining step [2-8]. The oxidation reaction over supported Rh is particularly adapted for infrared study because CO adsorbs on supported Rh in several well-characterized states as shown below [9-12]. Species 1, the "gem dicarbonyl" species, is character- 0 `0 0 h/ Rh Rh ized by two sharp infrared bands near 2030 and 2100 em-1 which do not shift significantly in frequency with coverage and hence have been attributed to the symmetric and antisymmetric stretching modes of CO bonded to isolated Rh sites [9-12] , although this issue concerning the dispersion of the Rh remains 286 controversial [13-15] . Also, the Rh in species I is almost certainly in the +1 oxidation state [10-12,16, 17]. Generally catalysts prepared with low Rh loading (0.5% Rh/support) contain only this surface species. If the species I sites were not isolated a shift in frequency with coverage of the two vibrational bands would be expected due to dipole-dipole interaction [18], local feld effects [19,20], vibrational coupling [20] , or changes in metal-carbon backbonding due to the change in CO coverage [21 ]. However, electron-microscopy experiments for similar supported Rh catalysts containing low loading (1% Rh/A1203) have indicated that species I sites are composed of "rafts" containing at least eight Rh atoms [13], and recent EXAFS data [14,15] have shown that 0.5% Rh/A1203 catalysts do contain some clusters with the adsorption of CO possibly causing disruption of the clusters [ 15] . Species 11, the "linear CO" species, and species III, the "bridged carbonyl" species, exhibit infrared bands in the 2040-2080 and 1850-1950 cm-1 regions, respectively, which do shift to higher frequency as coverage increases and must correspond to Rh metal cluster sites. The order of reactivity of these states with oxygen to produce carbon dioxide has been of interest in these laboratories as well as elsewhere [22,23]. This paper will report some of our recent findings in 0 009-2614/85/5 03.30 Elsevier Science Publishers B.V. (North-Holland Physics Publishing Division) Volume 114, number 3 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 1 March 1985 this regard as well as a new surface species for CO/ Rh/Ti02. 2. Experimental The supported Rh catalysts used in this study were prepared as 0.5% or 10.0% by weight Rh/X (X = A1203 Ti02, Si02) films by spraying a slurry of appropriate amounts of RhC13 -3H20, support material, nine parts spectroscopic grade acetone, and one part water onto a heated 25 mm CaF2 infrared window using a specially designed atomizer. Evaporation of the solvents left a uniform film of RhC13 -3H20/X on the window which was then positioned in a Pyrex infrared cell/ reactor of the type designed and used here previously [1,10-12] . Following evacuation to ~3 X 10-6 Tort, the samples were heated under vacuum at 430 K for 2 h. Then three reduction cycles (Matheson Research Grade hydrogen) at 75 Torr for periods of 20, 10, and 5 min were performed, with evacuation between each cyle. The samples were heated for an additional hour at 440 K under vacuum and then cooled to ambient temperature and evacuated until the base pressure was at least 3 X 10-6 Torr. At this time mixtures of 2 parts CO, 1 part 02 generally at a total pressure of -=21 Torr were introduced into the cell, and the infrared spectra were recorded as a function of temperature. The RhC13 -3H20 employed was obtained from Alfa Products, Inc. and used without further purification. The support materials used were alumina (Degussa aluminium oxide C, 100 m2 g- I ), titania (Degussa titanium oxide P25, 50 m2 g- 1), and silica (Cabot Cab-O-Sil M-5, 200 m2 g-I). The degrees of Rh dispersion for the various supported Rh catalyst films were not determined. All gases were of the highest purity obtainable from Matheson. The infrared spectra were generated by a Perkin-Elmer 983 spectrometer which was interfaced to a PerkinElmer data station. The data station was used for storage and manipulation of the spectra, particularly for difference spectra. The spectrometer was operated at a resolution of 5 cm- I in the 3000-1200 cm- I region. A quantitative determination of the yield of C02 was not made in this study. 3. Results and discussion The behavior of the adsorbed CO species infrared bands under oxidation reaction conditions must be highly dependent upon the method sample preparation. Arai and Tominaga [22] observed that for a pressed Rh/A1203 disk (unspecified weight percentage of Rh) reduced at 673 K and exposed to 50 Torr CO at 298 K, followed by evacuation and exposure to OZ at 50 Tort, the species II and III bands disappeared rapidly leaving only the gem dicarbonyl species I bands. Upon heating, the species I bands finally disappeared at 573 K. It is well known that the order of disappearance of the surface species for supported Rh catalysts under evacuation in the absence of 02 and under heating is I > II > III [9-12, 22] even though the order is III > II for Rh single crystals [21 ] (no I can be present on metallic Rh). It has been observed in these laboratories also that following high-temperature reduction (673 K) of a 10% Rh/A1203 film and exposure to Co followed by evacuation, the species I infrared bands dominate upon exposure to 02 at 298 K or at 673 K [10]. Kiss and Gonzalez [23] have shown recently that upon exposure of a 3% Rh/Si02 pressed disk, reduced at 650 K, to a flowing stream of a CO/02 mixture and upon heating to reaction ignition conditions, the order of disappearance was II, III > I. They concluded that the oxidation rate of CO decreases in the sequence Rh(0) > Rh(+1) > Rh(+1 to +3) and that a new infrared band at 2104 cm- I may be assigned to a CO/Rh surface species in which Rh is oxidized to at least +1 and possibly as high as +3. Figs. 1-3 show the results of heating prereduced 10% Rh/X (X =A1203, Ti02, and Si02) films to various temperatures in the presence of CO : 02 mixtures (2 : 1). For all three samples C02 formation was first observed (by infrared) at -380 K, and the intensities of all CO bands decreased at higher temperatures. In the case of 10% Rh/A1203 (fig. 1) the order of disappearance of the surface CO species was clearly III > I > II, and a small band at 2130 cm- I in the 410 K spectrum can be assigned to CO bonded to Rh(+3) [10]. Thus we find that for a 10% Rh/A1203 film exposed to a mixture of C02 and 02, that the linear species II is longest-lived upon raising the temperature. A 0.5% Rh/A1203 sample under the same reaction conditions gave infrared spectra (not shown) Volume 114, number 3 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 1 March 1985 10% Rh/Si02 0.4 10% Rh/A1203 e (e 430'K co 450 'K 1'K ) ~30 Z d 410 OK cc d 380oK 0 0 C 360 K W C) 380 OK c) 38 K d ) Mo K r oK )360 2 to. V 0 ( b3200K N 43 O'K b 320~ K ( :A b) 320 K (8) 300K N N 2500 2000 1800 1800 ( a ) 300 K WAVENUMBER(CM- 1 ) 3000 2000 140 1200 Fig. 2. Infrared spectra of a 10% Rh/Si02 film (4.7 mg cm-2 WAVENUMBER(CM-1) as a function of temperature in the presence of 14.0 Torr CO/7.0 Torr 0-2: (a) 300 K; (b) 30 min at 320 K; (c) 30 min Fig. 1. Infrared spectra of a 10% Rh/A12 03 film (3.9 mg at 360 K; (d) 30 min at 380 K; (e) 30 min at 410 K, then 30 cm-z) as a function of temperature in the presence of 14.0 min at 430 K. Torr CO/7.0 Torr 02: (a) 300 K; (b) 30 min at 320 K; (c) 30 min at 350 K, then 30 min at 380 K; (d) 30 min at 410 K; (e) 30 min at 430 K; (f) 30 min at 450 K. with only species I bands present, as expected for the highly dispersed catalyst. The C02 band near 2340 cm-1 had comparable intensity to that for the 10% Rh catalyst at a given temperature; this demonstates that the gem dicarbonyl species as well as species II and III can be oxidized to C02. However, it should be noted that a substantial amount of C02 is produced over all of the support materials (A1203, Si02, and Ti02) in the absence of Rh beginning at 460 K. The infrared spectra of the blank supports do not contain any bands in the 1800-2100 cm-1 region which could be attributed to adsorbed CO. The infrared spectra of the 10% Rh/Si02-sample 288 are shown in fig. 2; unfortunately these spectra are complicated by the presence of background Si02 bands in the 2000 cm-1 region making the observation of the bridged carbonyl (III) band behaviour difficult. Nevertheless, employing difference spectra, we believe that the order of disappearance of the surface species upon increasing temperature for Rh/ Si02 in this study was I > III > II. We could not detect any bands above 2100 cm-1 characteristic of Rh in a higher oxidation state than +1. Clearly the linear CO surface species is dominant at temperatures above 380 K. For a 0.5% Rh/Si02 film the gem dicarbonyl species I bands were considerably less intense than was the case for 0.5% Rh/A1203. Furthermore, difference spectra show a very weak species II Volume 114, number 3 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 1 March 1985 (linear CO) band which disappears last upon heating. This represents the first detection in these laboratories of a linear CO surface state on a 0.5% Rh catalyst film and probably is indicative of the greater ease of reduction of Rh on'Si02 as compared to A1203 [12]. It possibly also indicates that some Rh cluster sites are present on 0.5% Rh/Si02. The infrared spectra of the 10% Rh/Ti02 film (fig. 3) show that the order of disappearance of the surface species upon heating was I > III > II as was the case for 10% Rh/Si02 . It has been observed here [10-12] that 0.5% Rh/X films give symmetric and antisymmetric stretching mode bands for the gem di- w U Z m 0 m m (f ) 430K ( e ) 410 K 2040 (d) 380 K (C) 350 K ( b ) 320 K /Ti02 ( a ) 300 K 10% Rh 2000 1800 1200 WAVENUMBER(CM-1) Fig. 3. Infrared spectra of a 10% Rh/Ti02 film (4.7 mg cm-2. as a function of temperature in the presence of 14.0 Torr CO/7.0 Torr 02: (a) 300 K; (b) 30 min at 320 K; (c) 30 min at 350 K; (d) 30 min at 380 K; (e) 30 min at 410 K; (f) 30 min at 430 K. carbonyl species I with roughly equal integrated intensities. However, for 10% Rh/X films the component near 2030 cm--1 always exhibits higher integrated intensity. This is in part due to overlap with the species II band, but it also indicates the presence of another surface state [10]. This is demonstrated conclusively in fig. 4 which shows infrared spectra for a 0.5% Rh/Ti02 film exposed to the mixture of CO/02. Note that a new band is clearly resolved at 2000 cm-1. Solymosi and co-workers have mentioned a shoulder near 2000 cm-1 for a 0.3% Rh/ Ti02 disk exposed to CO [24]. They assigned this shoulder to a CO surface state on the Ti02 support [24] . However, we saw no evidence for such a band for our blank Ti02 film. Thus the presence of Rh is f )aso K e 1 430 K (d>41o K 0.5 I Rh/ T i02 ( C ) 380 K ( h ) 320 K y ( a ) 300 K T 2000 WAVENUMBER(CM-1) 1800 Fig. 4. Infrared spectra of a 0.5% Rh/Ti02 film (4.7 mg cm-2 as a function of temperature in the presence of 14.0 Torr CO/7.0 Torr Oz : (a) 300 K; (b) 30 min at 320 K; (c) 30 min at 380 K; (d) 30 min at 410 K; (e) 30 min at 430 K; (f) 30 min at 450 K. 289 Volume 114, number 3 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 1 March 1985 obviously necessary for the existence of this state. The frequency (2000 em-1) is too high to correspond to a bridged carbonyl on a RhO cluster. We believe that the state represents a bridged carbonyl between an isolated RhI+ ion and the support. This is consistent with the observation of higher CO stretching mode frequencies for oxidized Rh (RhI+ in species 1, 2030/2100 cm- I ; Rh2+, 2120 cm-I, Rh3+, 2136 cut- I) [10] . The 2000 cm-I band was riot resolved in the spectra for 0.5% Rh/A]203 or 0.5% Rh/Si02, but we cannot completely rule out its presence as a low-frequency shoulder on the 2030 cm- I species I band component. It should also be noted that the 2100 cm- I component for 0.5% Rh/Ti02 was abnormally intense (fig. 4). This could indicate the presence of a third surface state on this film. We have observed a similar effect near 2100 cm- I for a 10% Rh/A1203 sample oxidized at 673 K before exposure to CO at 298 K [10]. We believe that this new state near 2100 cm- I represents a single linear CO on RhI + [ 10] , or possibly to CO on a higher oxidation state of Rh as alluded to be Gonzalez and co-workers [23] for their Rh/Si02 disk. 4. Conclusions We are not certain why our results differ from those reported in other laboratories [22,23], or even our own for a different type of experiments (exposure to CO followed by evacuation and subsequent oxidation), as regards the stability of the linear CO species II in a heated CO/02 mixture. We can only surmise that our sample-preparation procedures were substantially different in this study. Our low-temperature reduction probably led to a catalyst film dominated by RhI +. It is even possible that the stable linear CO state which we have observed really refers to a RhI + monocarbonyl species. Finally, we have observed for the first time a wellresolved band near 2000 cm- I for CO/Rh/Ti02 which has been assigned to a bridged carbonyl species involving an isolated RhI+ ion and the Ti02 support. 290 Acknowledgement We gratefully acknowledge the support of the Office of Naval Research for this work. The frequency (2000 em-1) is too high to correspond to a bridged carbonyl on a RhO cluster. We believe that the state represents a bridged carbonyl between an isolated RhI+ ion and the support. This is consistent with the observation of higher CO stretching mode frequencies for oxidized Rh (RhI+ in species 1, 2030/2100 cm- I ; Rh2+, 2120 cm-I, Rh3+, 2136 cut- I) [10] . The 2000 cm-I band was riot resolved in the spectra for 0.5% Rh/A]203 or 0.5% Rh/Si02, but we cannot completely rule out its presence as a low-frequency shoulder on the 2030 cm- I species I band component. Conclusions We are not certain why our results differ from those reported in other laboratories [22,23], or even our own for a different type of experiments (exposure to CO followed by evacuation and subsequent oxidation), as regards the stability of the linear CO species II in a heated CO/02 mixture. We can only surmise that our sample-preparation procedures were substantially different in this study. Our low-temperature reduction probably led to a catalyst film dominated by RhI +. It is even possible that the stable linear CO state which we have observed really refers to a RhI + monocarbonyl species. head.ce:title: An infrared study of the oxidation of carbon monoxide over supported rhodium catalysts

ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: Department of Chemistry, Auburn University, Auburn, AL 36849, USA

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: The reaction of carbon monoxide and oxygen over supported rhodium films has been studied using infrared spectroscopy. The focus of the work was the reactivity of the various CO/Rh/X (X = Al2O3, SiO2, TiO2) surface states for supported catalysts having high and low Rh loading. Under the reaction conditions the “linear CO” species was the most stable toward oxidation, but this could have been a result of an oxidized Rh surface. A new CO/Rh surface species has been proposed which exhibits an infrared band at 2000 cm−1 for a 0.5% Rh/TiO2 film. This species is believed to be a bridged carbonyl between Rh1+ and the TiO2 support.

sb:title.sb:maintitle: J. Chem. Soc. Faraday Trans I
